newsitem.title: USA: San Francisco area home prices surge 8.8 pct.
newsitem.headline: San Francisco area home prices surge 8.8 pct.

text.p: Home prices in the San Francisco Bay area rose 8.8 percent in April to levels not seen since their 1989-1991 peaks, according to a survey released on Tuesday.

The median price paid for a resale house in the nine-county Bay area was $260,000 last month, up 8.8 percent from $239,000 in March and up 11.6 percent from $233,000 for April last year, the DataQuick survey said.
"Today's Bay area home market is stronger than it was six years ago," said Mike Ela, DataQuick's president.
Ela said Bay area home prices have now regained virtually all the lost ground of the recession.
A total of 5,891 resale houses were sold in the nine-county Bay area last month, up 18.3 percent from 4,979 in March and up 8.7 percent from 4,642 for April last year, the survey said.

The Bay area has recorded year-over-year increases in sales volume for the last year-and-a-half. If current trends stayed in place, 1997 would see the highest number of homes sold since 1989, the survey said.
A total of 1,441 Bay area resale condominiums were sold in April, up 27.2 percent from 1,133 a year ago. The median price was $179,000, up 3.5 percent from $173,000 a year ago, the survey said.
A total of 1,148 newly-built homes were sold last month, up 29.3 percent from 888 a year ago. The median price was $251,000, up 3.7 percent from $242,000 in 1996, DataQuick reported.
DataQuick monitors real estate purchasing and financing nationwide.
The nine-county Bay area includes Alameda, Contra Costa, Marin, Napa, San Francisco, San Mateo, Santa Clara, Solano and Sonoma counties.
